text: reports from the United States that one
of the two attackers accused of killing
14 people at a mass shooting in
California posted an online statement
pledging allegiance to the leader of the
so-called Islamic state militant group
Abu Bakr al-baghdadi the pledge was
apparently made by the female shooter
tashfeen Malik on Facebook using a
different name well our correspondent in
Washington Kari O'Donoghue gave me an
update one of the attackers tashfeen
Malik it appears that she may have under
another name separate identity she may
have posted some sort of pledge of
allegiance to the Islamic state to the
head of Islamic state al Baghdadi in the
run-up to these attacks certainly
officials are not are not steering
people away from that conclusion we also
understand that the two may have been
trying to destroy some of their sort of
electronic footprint before these
attacks took place and of course these
facts if they turn out so or if they
turn out to be facts then that would
start to push the investigation I'm sure
from the FBI's point of view towards the
idea that this was significantly
motivated by extremist views Islamic
extremist views and it's being reported
that they might have pledged allegiance
but no evidence to say that this was
directed by is that is quite an
important distinction isn't it but in
any case all very alarming yeah I mean
bear in mind that there's a concern
certainly in this country amongst their
enforcement officials about what are
called lone Wolf's people who in a sense
sort of take up the radical agenda from
what they see online from what they see
on the television that they're not in
any sense part of a kind of formal
Network but are inspired by what is
going on elsewhere and you've seen that
actually in the last few days that is
that means they haven't really claimed
responsibility for this in the way they
did for example with the Paris attacks
and with the the downing of the the
Russian airliner in Egypt so that would
sort of fit
into that explanation if that's what's
happening here and also I think the the
evidence that's now emerging about the
amount of weaponry the amount of
explosives they had in in their homes
and when we're talking about pipe bombs
hundreds and hundreds of rounds of
ammunition as well a number of weapons
does suggest that some there was some
sort of planning in this process some
sort of organization that the idea that
it was just some sort of arguments at
work I think is is now obviously
diminishing in insignificance
